column4: The presence of haptic feedback was helpful in completing the task.
column5: The guidewire detection software felt stable and predictable.
column6: Guidewire tracking with MR slice movement was helpful.
column7: I felt stressed, irritated or annoyed while using this system during the task.
column8: It was easy to control/use the system.
column9: It was easy to make mistakes with the system.
column10: Staying focused on what I was doing was easy.
column11: The system was safe to use.
column12: I would like to use the system again for this kind of task.
column13: I would recommend this system to a colleague.

column14: Showing the direction of movement on the controller, and showing which side of the button is on/off for the guidewire and catheter controls. And maybe finding the hardware issue that's making the reset mandatory every couple movements ;p
Can superimpose images to see the whole instrument, spline of the guidewire shape

A wonderful first concept but due to lack of any reliable visual feedback of the interaction between wire and catheter it's feels like a lucky gues and not an handy interaction between my  hand/eye coordination and what the robot is doing.
Always wire first to prevent wall damage and we must see wire and catheter both. Rotation and pushing upwards the wire is a combined action with the eye the surgeon
